name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: COVID-19 is the single greatest threat to the physical wellbeing of all Ohioans, the mental health of our citizens, and our economic security. As your Governor, I took an oath that, with it, comes the solemn responsibility to do everything I can to protect and preserve life.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: These next several weeks will be the toughest yet.  Weâ€™re heading into the biggest holiday season on our calendar, while riding the biggest wave of COVID-19 that weâ€™ve had so far.  What each of us does in the next 21 days will set us on the path - good or bad - for the next year.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: CJ Adams: At first we were seeing an older population, but right now we are seeing more of a younger crowd: 40s, 50s, 60s and healthy. This adds to the fear that COVID really is impacting everyone.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: On Dec. 22, we anticipate a shipment of 201,000 vaccines from Moderna. These will go to 98 hospitals and 108 health departments. Hospitals will vaccinate those dealing with COVID patients. Health departments will vaccinate people like EMS. There are other examples also.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Phase 1A of distribution priorities - in no particular order â¬‡  â—¾ Healthcare workers and personnel who are involved in the care of COVID-19 patients  â—¾ EMS responders â—¾ Vulnerable individuals who live together in close proximity and those who care for them â¬‡  https://t.co/jJ6HiEylWX

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Dr. Vanderhoff: If you become sick or test positive for COVID-19, stay home and self-isolate â€” that means staying at home and in a separate room from others.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Dr. Vanderhoff: We also recommend 14 days if you are in contact with people at increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19. For others, with no symptoms, the 10-day period may be sufficient.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Dr. Vanderhoff: I want to be clear. Staying home for 14 days after contact is still the safest way to limit possible spread of COVID-19. We continue to recommend this time period for people in congregate living facilities.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Dr. Vanderhoff: We ask people to quarantine - to stay in their homes for several days - after they have had close contact w/ someone w/ COVID. This helps prevent spread of the disease, because it can be carried and transmitted by people even if they never show symptoms.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: As #COVID19 spreads in Ohio, it's impacting our healthcare workers. When they are sick, they can't help others. It's up to all of us to #SlowTheSpread and protect those on the frontline like Stephanie, a respiratory therapist who is now suffering from COVID complications. â¬‡  https://t.co/ojOp0nbTbW

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Jamie Giere: When patients are #COVID positive, they can't have a loved one hold their hand. They can't have a loved one by their side. You can see the fear in their faces and it's heartbreaking.

tweet: A number of people across Ohio have been able to work from home since the pandemic began.  At this time of a great increase in cases and as we see our hospitals fill up with COVID patients, I again ask anyone who can work from home to do so.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Dr. Brian Kaminski: COVID cases are trending upward at an alarming rate in our area. Our rate of hospitalized patients has tripled, and we expect that number to grow. I want to be clear that there is no doubt that our hospital systems will be overwhelmed as the numbers go up.

name: Governor Mike DeWine

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Dr. Canady: I think there is COVID-fatigue, so to speak, in southeast Ohio. I think we did a really good job in the spring, but then we got a little lax. It's not a virus that stays in the big cities, it will go anywhere.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: As we have throughout this pandemic, we will continue to offer state resources and support to help fight COVID-19 at the local level.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: The remaining money will be used to hire contact tracers to support local health departments. Those tracers would be able to deploy wherever they are needed across the state to assist in identifying individuals who may have been exposed to COVID-19 and prevent further spread.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: We are setting aside $30 million dollars to assist the stateâ€™s 113 local health departments. Each department will receive $200,000 and they will have the flexibility to determine how to best use the funds as they see fit to fight COVID-19.  https://t.co/j0RBmOuFPM

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Left shows ED visits with a diagnosis code of COVID-like symptoms & COVID concern. Right shows the number of ED visits with a confirmed diagnosis of COVID-19.  Both graphs show an alarming trend and that our emergency departments are facing more cases.  https://t.co/NJhNpSc6OM

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: This graph shows the 7-day moving average outpatient visits for patients with either a confirmed or suspected COVID-19 diagnosis code. The trend is similar to those we are seeing for case counts as well as hospitalizations.  https://t.co/fBUOB2UCmy

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Even our family and our closest friends can bring COVID into our homes.  They donâ€™t do it intentionally, but it happens when they donâ€™t know they have the virus. We just need to avoid any unnecessary and additional risks right now.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: We know that masks work.  It is the easiest, most cost-effective way to limit the spread of COVID-19.  Every retail employee has the right to work in an environment that is as safe as can be, which means all customers must wear masks.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Yesterday, I received a letter from a school superintendent concerned about community spread.  She said people â€œdonâ€™t seem to understand that while COVID exposures are occurring outside of the school setting, they are having a profound effect on our ability to remain open.â€

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: This state of emergency supports hospitalsâ€™ ongoing efforts to make staffing adjustments in accordance with CDC guidance, as they work to care for our rising number of COVID hospital patients.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: If we donâ€™t change this, we wonâ€™t be able to provide appropriate care for all the Ohioans who need it for COVID and for all those Ohioans who require other emergency care for things like accidents, strokes, and heart attacks.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Today, hospitals are functioning as if at the peak of the flu season in January. But unlike the flu, when personnel know cases will begin to drop in late winter/early spring, these new COVID cases arenâ€™t trending down. It is taking an enormous human toll on healthcare workers.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Despite great work by medical personnel and improved COVID treatments, too many of our fellow citizens are dying. In the first week of October, 86 Ohioans died from COVID.  With many more Ohioans testing positive today, we know that number will surely grow. It already has.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Weâ€™ve learned during the pandemic that what happens today may not reveal its full impact for weeks. This is true of hospitalizations, and sadly, also true of deaths. The reality is that we wonâ€™t know the ultimate fate of those diagnosed w/ COVID today for weeks or even months.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Ohio also has a record number of patients in our Intensive Care Units.  A month ago, 240 patients with COVID were in the ICU receiving critical care. Tonight, more than 700 of our fellow Ohioans are in the ICU.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: During the spring and summer virus surges, the most COVID patients in the hospital at one time was a little over 1,100. Last week, we were at almost 2,000 COVID patients in our hospitals.  Today - one week later - we are approaching 3,000.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Tonight, I will deliver a statewide address to discuss the critical stage Ohio has entered in our battle with COVID-19 and the impact on Ohio moving forward.   #InThisTogetherOhio  https://t.co/3lWx4IRScb  https://t.co/1HvxNwcMAQ

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Tomorrow, I will deliver a statewide address to discuss the critical stage Ohio has entered in our battle with COVID-19 and the impact on Ohio moving forward.   #InThisTogetherOhio  https://t.co/3lWx4IRScb  https://t.co/TdIEw54ARQ

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: They live in our communities and they can't escape the impact of rising COVID numbers. When they have to quarantine, they can't be anywhere else. We need your help with masking, distancing, and hand hygiene. #InThisTogetherOhio

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Dr. Vanderhoff: We are grappling with unprecedented COVID numbers and they're impacting every community. Our hospitals statewide are reaching maximum capacity b/c we are exhausting the available supply of trained personnel - nurses, physicians, pharmacists, and others.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: It's time to pay attention and get serious. The spread of COVID-19 is getting worse by the minute. The government is not going to come knocking on your door to make sure you aren't having a party -- we all have a personal responsibility to take precautions and stay safe.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: We can turn this around. COVID-19 is multiplying very quickly - and it will continue unless we do something different. More of us need to wear masks, and more of us need to be careful. We've done it before, and we can do it again. #InThisTogetherOhio

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: CLARK COUNTY: Clark County is on the watch list for the first time since the alert system started four months ago. The county also exceeds the CDCâ€™s threshold for high incidence. Local health department officials report that there are 30 people hospitalized for COVID.

tweet: In half of our new red counties, there are outbreaks related to funerals or weddings. In one example, there was a wedding where two grandfathers died due to COVID. Examples like these are absolutely heartbreaking.

tweet: As we said in August and September, spread among the young and healthy will eventually impact those who are older and more vulnerable.  The average age of COVID cases has gone up, and unfortunately, so has the average age of hospitalizations.  https://t.co/r5sDAcO9Em

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Fran and I join our fellow Ohioans in praying for President Trump and First Lady Melania Trump after they announced early today that they have both tested positive for COVID-19.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: A man was in ICU for a non-COVID related reason. The hospital tested him and he was negative. His wife continued to come to visit him but refused to wear a mask. She started feeling ill after a few days and tested positive. Now, her husband also is COVID positive.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: A husband in his 80s passed away of a non-COVID related cause. His funeral was in a neighboring state and his 85-year-old widow attended. name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: The test administered this morning to the Governor in Cleveland, as part of the protocol required to meet the President, was an antigen test.  These tests represent a new technology to reduce the cost and improve the turnaround time for COVID-19 testing, but they are quite new.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: A PCR test was administered to the Governor and members of his staff this afternoon.  The PCR test looks for the specific RNA for the SARS CoV-2 -- in other words, the genetic material specific for the virus that causes COVID-19.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Therefore, I am asking the @OhioRxBoard to halt their new rule prohibiting the selling or dispensing of hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine for the treatment or prevention of COVID-19.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: When child care reopened, I vowed to monitor the data and make adjustments as needed.  We will continue to closely monitor reports of COVID in child care, as well as compliance with rules and best practices, and respond as needed to keep our children, families, and teachers safe.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: It is especially important to take care of yourself right now, and your mental health is just as important as your physical health. If you need to talk with someone, call the @OhioMHAS COVID Careline: 1-800-720-9616.   #InThisTogetherOhio

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Ohio is now nearing our April and May peak of 1,100 hospital patients, with the #Cincinnati and #Dayton regions currently seeing more COVID-positive patients in the hospital than during any previous time during the pandemic. The #Cleveland region nearing a similar point.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Our hospitals are seeing more and more #COVID19 patients. There are 1,027 of our fellow citizens in our hospitals suffering from COVID today.  316 are in intensive care.   146 are on a ventilator.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: â¡ @LtGovHusted: Convalescent plasma, which is plasma from recovered #COVID19 patients, is rich in antibodies that could possibly attack the virus that causes COVID-19. It shows promise to lessen the severity or shorten the length of COVID-19.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: From 6-16 to 7-1, visits for #COVID19 to the ER more than doubled from an average of 19 per day to 50.  Over the same time period, the average number of outpatient visits with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 diagnoses increased from 41 to 233.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: This funding comes from federal CARES Act dollars and schools would be able to use it to meet their unique individual needs.  We intend for this funding to be very flexible to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: BUTLER COUNTY: Meting four of seven indicators. As of this past week, the average new cases in Butler County per day doubled.  The number of COVID-positive patients in the Southwest Regionâ€™s hospital beds and ICUs has also doubled since the second week of June.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: SUSTAINED INCREASE IN NEW #COVID19 HOSPITAL ADMISSIONS: When the numbers show at least a five-day period of sustained growth in the number of county residents with COVID-19 who are admitted to a hospital, the county will be flagged for meeting this indicator.  https://t.co/0imvAw381c

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: SUSTAINED INCREASE IN ER VISITS: ER data will show us the trend in the number of people who visit an emergency department with #COVID19 symptoms or a COVID diagnosis as a result of the visit.  A county is flagged when there is an increase in such ER visits over a five-day period.  https://t.co/qjzK3rnrYU

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Local health departments are mapping #COVID19 transmission.  Theyâ€™ve reported to the @OHdeptofhealth  information about how COVID-19 is spreading. It's spreading at large family gatherings, protests, at the workplace, bars, restaurants, tourist destinations.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Because of the importance of face masks in slowing the spread of COVID-19, schools must establish a face mask policy.  In doing so, they should consider all the available science.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: COVID-specific hospital utilization is approaching levels not seen since the earlier peak of the pandemic in April.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: For the hospitals in our West Central region, the number of COVID-positive patients in standard hospital beds, ICUs, and ventilators have also doubled since the first week of June.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: The community is also experiencing early signs that more people are seeking medical care for COVID symptoms. For example, outpatient visits grew from an average of nearly 7 visits per day to 27.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: The number of COVID-positive patients being treated in standard hospital beds, ICU beds, and on ventilators has steadily increased. In fact, in Hamilton County, the number of COVID-positive patients has doubled from the low of 65 on June 11th to more than 130 this weekend.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: In Hamilton Co. and the surrounding Southwestern Ohio region, hospital utilization by COVID-19 positive patients reached their lowest levels of this epidemic during the first and second weeks of June.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: For example, more people are visiting their doctors more often and being diagnosed with COVID-19. In one weekâ€™s time in Hamilton County between June 15 and June 22, those numbers nearly doubled from 40 to 78 visits per day.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: The increase in #COVID19 hospital occupancy is most apparent in Regions 2, 3, and 6 (the Cleveland, Dayton, and Cincinnati areas). In other regions of the state, COVID hospital occupancy had been declining but now appears to have leveled off.  https://t.co/WXBpIlFoPf

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Last week was our first week of increasing #COVID19 hospital utilization after over 2 months of decreasing utilization since late April. The # of standard hospital beds occupied by COVID-19+ patients peaked in late April/early May at about 1,000 & reached a low of 513 on 6/20.  https://t.co/UGYBzXygnW

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: For #COVID19, the R0 is estimated at 2.5 (CDC). This means anyone with COVID-19 would give it to between two and three people if we took no interventions like washing hands, wearing masks, social distancing, and taking other prevention efforts.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: 3ï¸âƒ£ Maintaining a reliable supply chain to support their non-COVID-19 cases and to respond to an unexpected surge in COVID-19 cases, if needed.  4ï¸âƒ£ Defining processes for timely COVID-19 testing of patients and staff; and  5ï¸âƒ£ Continuing to use telehealth whenever possible.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: New â¡ We will begin the testing of all residents and staff members of the stateâ€™s developmental centers.  This is an important effort to try to limit the spread of COVID-19 in congregate care settings.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Cases have been detected in all 88 #Ohio counties.  The majority of hospital admissions and deaths are among adults ages 60 and older.  However, nearly half of reported COVID-19 cases in Ohio are among adults ages 30-59.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: #COVID19 is becoming one of the leading causes of death in #Ohio.  Preliminary research indicates that as of May 19, 2020, more than 90,000 people in the United States, including 1,657 Ohioans, have died with COVID-19.  These numbers continue to increase daily.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: From @CDCgov: There is no evidence that the virus that causes COVID-19 can be spread to people through the water in pools, hot tubs, spas, or water play areas. Proper operation/maintenance (disinfection w/ chlorine/bromine) of these facilities should inactivate the virus in water

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: Decisions like this are extremely difficult, but are part of my responsibility, as your governor, to make.  While we do not know what the coming months will hold, we do know that COVID-19 is here with us and will be here for quite some time.

name: Governor Mike DeWine
tweet: As we have all seen, COVID-19 has had a profound impact on the American economy.  And Ohio's economy as well. Prior to the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, Ohioâ€™s economy was strong and our budget was on track.
